Every rational real estate investor usually expects future returns on their investments. And due to the significance of the real estate industry to individuals and the national development of any country, this course focuses on the systematic analysis of the principles and methods of contemporary property investment performance analysis.

Formal written examination including short answers, essay-style questions and calculation questions.

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO1","cl_id":"12af1e2bdbb99850eb6b147a3a961910","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO2","cl_id":"5eaf1e2bdbb99850eb6b147a3a961912","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO3","cl_id":"9aaf1e2bdbb99850eb6b147a3a961915","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO4","cl_id":"d6af1e2bdbb99850eb6b147a3a961918","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"02afda2bdbb99850eb6b147a3a9619f1","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Group asssignment","assessment_type":{"label":"Report","value":"report"},"assessment_id":"3","weighting":"30","description":"

A group of five students will analyse the property investment environments of top property markets around the world and apply the DCF model, NPV and IRR in making investment decisions in a particular property market, which is aimed at investigation of property investment environments. The deliverables are a group report (3500 words) and a group oral presentation.

","erg":[],"campus":{"name":""}},"additional_information":"","study_level_tooltip":"Postgraduate: A level of study that leads to the award of a Graduate Certificate, Graduate Diploma, Masters Degree or Doctorate.","campus":"Sydney","study_level_single":{"label":"Postgraduate","value":"pgrd"},"code":"REST0004","attributes":[],"credit_points_header":"6 Units of Credit","eqivalents":[],"exclusion":[],"search_title":"REST0004 - Property Investment and Finance","description":"

This course provides insight into property investment and ?nance in Australia and internationally. It introduces the concept of property investment and finance concepts. It explores the unique features of income-producing property, property development and examines the performance of these properties through the application of a variety of investment techniques. Students critically review equity and debt ?nancing and examine the ?nancing alternatives available, as well as methods for evaluating these alternatives. In addition, students gain both a theoretical and an applied understanding of basic accounting principles this course. The role of real estate in a capital market is also examined through a portfolio analysis. The contemporary issues (e.g. sustainability in property investment, macro economic impacts and real estate legal implications) are also addressed. This enables students to develop a high level of knowledge of the workings of modern-day real estate capital markets.


","hb_assessments":[{"delivery_variation":{"cl_id":"e0e3edbfdb7d1c50eb6b147a3a961963","name":"Blended in-person / online - Standard (usually weekly or fortnightly)"},"assessments":[{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"A market report of a property investment (individual assignment)","assessment_type":{"label":"Report","value":"report"},"assessment_id":"1","weighting":"40","description":"

Individual assignment: A market report of a property investment. It consists two sections (Section A is to identify a property; 10% (week 3), whilst Section B; 30% (week 5), is the full market report).

The individual assignment focuses on demonstrating an understanding of real estate markets, financial markets, green property regulations and applying this to create an investment strategy outcome.

Opportunity for consultation with course lecturer is embedded into the course design incorporating feedback on work in progress and feedback on final report.

contentlets.keywords: real estate,property capital market,portfolio theory,property investment strategy
contentlets.description: This course provides insight into property investment and ?nance in Australia and internationally. It introduces the concept of property investment and finance concepts. It explores the unique features of income-producing property, property development and examines the performance of these properties through the application of a variety of investment techniques. Students critically review equity and debt ?nancing and examine the ?nancing alternatives available, as well as methods for evaluating these alternatives. In addition, students gain both a theoretical and an applied understanding of basic accounting principles this course. The role of real estate in a capital market is also examined through a portfolio analysis. The contemporary issues (e.g. sustainability in property investment, macro economic impacts and real estate legal implications) are also addressed. This enables students to develop a high level of knowledge of the workings of modern-day real estate capital markets.
contentlets.title: Property Investment and Finance

","erg":[],"campus":{"name":""}},"additional_information":"","study_level_tooltip":"Postgraduate: A level of study that leads to the award of a Graduate Certificate, Graduate Diploma, Masters Degree or Doctorate.","campus":"Sydney","study_level_single":{"label":"Postgraduate","value":"pgrd"},"code":"REST0005","attributes":[],"credit_points_header":"6 Units of Credit","eqivalents":[],"exclusion":[],"search_title":"REST0005 - Property Valuation","description":"

Property valuation remains one of the most important specializations in the real estate profession. This is because valuers are specially educated and trained to carry out property valuations for the public due to the peculiarity and importance of real estate assets. Hence, this course provides a graduate-level introduction to property valuation theory and practice.  The topics to be discussed include the concept of value, purpose and basis of property valuation, methods of property valuation (both traditional and advanced), property valuation process and property valuation report and an introduction to the application of computer programs in property valuation.

","erg":[],"campus":{"name":""}},"additional_information":"","study_level_tooltip":"Postgraduate: A level of study that leads to the award of a Graduate Certificate, Graduate Diploma, Masters Degree or Doctorate.","campus":"Sydney","study_level_single":{"label":"Postgraduate","value":"pgrd"},"code":"REST0006","attributes":[],"credit_points_header":"6 Units of Credit","eqivalents":[],"exclusion":[],"search_title":"REST0006 - Property Development and Feasibility Analysis","description":"

This course examines the process of property development and feasibility analysis of property development projects. It investigates the meaning and scope of real property and sustainable property development, development process and participants, as well as development appraisal procedures for producing good development outcomes. It introduces computer software of property development feasibility analysis, and it uses case studies to give students skills in organising and solving feasibility analysis problems. It is structured around lectures, tutorial sessions, and assessment is based on practical project-based assignments.


 


","hb_assessments":[{"delivery_variation":{"cl_id":"d44f5db3db7d1c50eb6b147a3a961999","name":"Blended in-person / online - Standard (usually weekly or fortnightly)"},"assessments":[{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Individual Report","assessment_type":{"label":"Report","value":"report"},"assessment_id":"1","weighting":"10","description":"

Application for Development Approval:

Students are asked to select a local government area (LGA) of their own choice and report on what information and documents the LGA requires to lodge an application for a development comprising a residential apartment project.

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO1","cl_id":"4c4f5db3db7d1c50eb6b147a3a961980","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"373f5db3db7d1c50eb6b147a3a96196e","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Group Assignment","assessment_type":{"label":"Assignment","value":"assignment"},"assessment_id":"2","weighting":"30","description":"

Planning control on a development:

Each group will consist of three students.  The group will be required to review the planning control of a nominated local government area (LGA) for a development in relation to the requirements of the Local Environment Plan, Development Control Plan, State Environmental Planning Policy and any other related legislation.

Each group member will be required to complete a peer assessment form to evaluate his/her performance and that of the other members.

Tutorial sessions will be arranged to provide feedback and critique to students.

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO2","cl_id":"404f5db3db7d1c50eb6b147a3a961990","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"7f3f5db3db7d1c50eb6b147a3a961972","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Individual Assignment","assessment_type":{"label":"Assignment","value":"assignment"},"assessment_id":"3","weighting":"60","description":"

Development Appraisal:

Students will be required to select a site in metropolitan Sydney for a proposed development project.  Based on a market research, they will be required to assess the land value that should be paid for the site, using the 'Hypothetical Development Approach', and to conduct a 'Cashflow Feasibility Analysis' to determine the development profitability.

Tutorial sessions will be arranged to provide feedback and critique to students.

","erg":[],"campus":{"name":""}},"additional_information":"","study_level_tooltip":"Postgraduate: A level of study that leads to the award of a Graduate Certificate, Graduate Diploma, Masters Degree or Doctorate.","campus":"Sydney","study_level_single":{"label":"Postgraduate","value":"pgrd"},"code":"REST0007","attributes":[],"credit_points_header":"6 Units of Credit","eqivalents":[],"exclusion":[],"search_title":"REST0007 - Asset and Facilities Management","description":"

This course examines the key issues in facilities management of building assets and how it, as a business resource, relates to organisation strategies and supports the business needs.  Strategic facilities management will be the focus of study, along with the consideration of operational facilities management.  Topics include strategic facilities review, planning and alignment, as well as facilities utilization and asset maintenance, facilities management support and organisation, and integration of facilities, property and asset management to achieve business and organisational needs, to ensure operational efficiency, and to preserve and enhance asset value and performance.      


","hb_assessments":[{"delivery_variation":{"cl_id":"8841613bdb7d1c50eb6b147a3a9619b8","name":"Blended in-person / online - Standard (usually weekly or fortnightly)"},"assessments":[{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Assignment 2: Specialist Study Report (individual work)","assessment_type":{"label":"Report","value":"report"},"assessment_id":"2","weighting":"50","description":"

Assignment 2 is an individual report (2000-2500 words).  Individuals are required to conduct specialist study upon TWO aspects of the selected property or businesses’ facilities management organisation to identify management issues, recommend remedies and state the economic/productivity benefits of implementing the recommendations of the study.  This individual assignment is a summative component leading to the final Assessment 3.

Dedicated tutorial sessions will be scheduled to provide guidance and feedback to assist students to prepare for the report.  Marking and feedback for the assignment will be provided online via moodle.   

Submission: due Week 8

 

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO2","cl_id":"4c41613bdb7d1c50eb6b147a3a9619a2","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO3","cl_id":"8841613bdb7d1c50eb6b147a3a9619a5","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO4","cl_id":"c441613bdb7d1c50eb6b147a3a9619a8","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"3331613bdb7d1c50eb6b147a3a961992","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Assignment 3: FM Audit Report (group work)","assessment_type":{"label":"Report","value":"report"},"assessment_id":"3","weighting":"30","description":"

Assignment 3 is group report (1000-1500 words from each group member).  The team will prepare a Facilities management Audit Report for examining management issues related to facilities assets and support services as well as FM organisation ( as revealed in the individual specialist study reports) and proposing an overall remedy plan for achieving the client's business operation and organisational needs.

Dedicated tutorial sessions will be scheduled to provide guidance and feedback to assist students to prepare for the report.  Marking and feedback for the assignment will be provided online via moodle.   

Submission: due Week 10

 

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO2","cl_id":"4c41613bdb7d1c50eb6b147a3a9619a2","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO3","cl_id":"8841613bdb7d1c50eb6b147a3a9619a5","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO4","cl_id":"c441613bdb7d1c50eb6b147a3a9619a8","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"7b31613bdb7d1c50eb6b147a3a961996","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Assignment 1: Preliminary Report (individual work)","assessment_type":{"label":"Report","value":"report"},"assessment_id":"1","weighting":"20","description":"

Students will form teams of 3 and select their own business and facilities for preparing a Facilities Management Audit Report, which involves examination of the facilities assets and support services as well as facilities organisation in order to produce a remedial plan for the clients’ business needs and benefits. Students will work as if they are professional consultants appointed to scrutinise their chosen case study.  The assignments are built upon this case study scenario.  Assignments 1 and 2 are individual reports, which form the inputs for the group report in Assignment 3.

Assignment 1 is an individual report (500-1000 words) which will form part of a 3-part preliminary business report which covers 1. business organisation and objectives, 2. core business activities, and 3. existing facitlies assets and support services, forming the basis for FM audit. This individual assignment is a summative component leading to the final Assessment 3.

Dedicated tutorial sessions will be scheduled to provide guidance and feedback to assist students to prepare for the report.  Marking and feedback for the assignment will be provided online via moodle.  

Submission: due Week 5

This course will present a comprehensive review and analysis of recent trends and current dynamics of the contemporary property investment and development industry in Australia. There will be an analysis of this Industry Sector (both development and investment) and it’s position as a leading contributor to the national economy, significant participant in financial markets and as a key employer in Australia. Supported by detailed case studies, and various lessons learnt, the course will cover commercial office, mixed commercial, retail, industrial, residential and other key sub-sectors of the property development and investment industry in Australia. Independent and group assignments will develop the student’s presentation and assessment reporting appropriate to current property industry and academic standards.

contentlets.description:
REST0018 Research Project is a research-based course. Complementing the pre-requisite knowledge gained, this course introduces you to the fundamentals of research implementation, data analysis, and research report (thesis) writing so as to provide you with an integral view of the research process.

Students enrolled in the Research Project are expected to take significant responsibility for their own learning. They are expected to conduct their own searches of the literature to identify cutting edge thinking and examples of projects relevant to their own research and professional practice and obtain their own data (primary and secondary) to inform their investigation. Students need to demonstrate a comprehensive understanding on: (i) the key issues and challenges facing students in undertaking research; (ii) at least one type of research approach, design, method and an appropriate data collection strategy including quantitative and qualitative data analysis techniques; and (iii) the research results presentation and thesis writing.
contentlets.title: Research Project

","erg":[],"campus":{"name":""}},"additional_information":"","study_level_tooltip":"Postgraduate: A level of study that leads to the award of a Graduate Certificate, Graduate Diploma, Masters Degree or Doctorate.","campus":"Sydney","study_level_single":{"label":"Postgraduate","value":"pgrd"},"code":"REST0019","attributes":[],"credit_points_header":"6 Units of Credit","eqivalents":[],"exclusion":[],"search_title":"REST0019 - Real Property Law","description":"

This course introduces students to the fundamental concepts of both commercial law and real property, providing an overview of the operation of the Australian legal system and foundational concepts in contract, tort and business law as well as a more detailed examination of legal doctrines, principles and rules governing property, land, tenure, title, possession, estates, successive and concurrent interests, priorities, covenants, easements, mortgages, charges and caveats for the purpose of equipping students to navigate dealings in land in NSW including the acquisition, sale, valuation, use and development of land as well as the resolution of disputes in relation to land.


 


","hb_assessments":[{"delivery_variation":{"cl_id":"d754d5b7dbf91c50eb6b147a3a96190d","name":"Blended in-person / online - Standard (usually weekly or fortnightly)"},"assessments":[{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Final examination","assessment_type":{"label":"Examination","value":"examination"},"assessment_id":"3","weighting":"50","description":"

Formal written examination, open book

This exam aims to test the students on:

(a) Fundamental principles of commercial law (contract, tort and business law) underpinning the framework of real property law in the Australian legal system.

(b) The statutory and jurisprudential principles and rules determining the entitlements and obligations incidental to proprietary interests recognised by real property law, along with their practical application to dealings in land and property development in NSW.

This assessment aims to test the students' basic legal knowledge in real property law and jurisprudence, as well as difference types of ownership and related rights, responsbilities and restrictons in NSW and Australia.

","erg":[],"campus":{"name":""}},"additional_information":"","study_level_tooltip":"Postgraduate: A level of study that leads to the award of a Graduate Certificate, Graduate Diploma, Masters Degree or Doctorate.","campus":"Sydney","study_level_single":{"label":"Postgraduate","value":"pgrd"},"code":"REST0022","attributes":[],"credit_points_header":"6 Units of Credit","eqivalents":[],"exclusion":[],"search_title":"REST0022 - Building Analytics","description":"

This course is an introduction to data analytics and is of high relevance to the construction and property industries considering the amount of data generated by organisations and in their projects. For example, project health and safety data, marketing strategies of companies, extreme weather conditions, building energy consumption, organisational performance and productivity data, employee absenteeism rate, rental and sales trends, etc. The ability to store, organize, retrieve and analyse relevant data is often touted to be one of the key factors driving project and organisational effectiveness and success.  In this course, students will be explored to basic database development and management and analytical procedures, and basic data analysis using Microsoft EXCEL.

","hb_assessments":[{"delivery_variation":{"cl_id":"10240dfbdb391c50eb6b147a3a961989","name":"Blended in-person / online - Standard (usually weekly or fortnightly)"},"assessments":[{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Individual Assignment","assessment_type":{"label":"Assignment","value":"assignment"},"assessment_id":"1","weighting":"50","description":"

The individual assignment is designed to evaluate students’ understanding on the development and management of database. Students are expected to submit their assignment (which include the excel file and written manual), via the Moodle Course Website. To facilitate learning, students will be given opportunities for consultation with the course convener as their assignment progresses. 

A conventional assessment process will be adopted, whereby students will be given a detailed assessment criteria together with the assignment brief. Upon completion of assessment, students will be given detailed comments as to how they could improve their work. 

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO1","cl_id":"84240dfbdb391c50eb6b147a3a961970","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO2","cl_id":"c0240dfbdb391c50eb6b147a3a961973","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"b7140dfbdb391c50eb6b147a3a961962","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Group Assignment","assessment_type":{"label":"Assignment","value":"assignment"},"assessment_id":"2","weighting":"50","description":"

The group assignment is designed to evaluate students’ understanding on: (i) the data analytical life-cycle; (ii) the design of appropriate data collection instrument or database; and (iii) the application of appropriate analytical procedures. Students will work into a group of 3.

 

The team leader of respective groups must submit the business research report, via the Moodle Course Website. Further to this, the leader should ensure that:

·        the names of all group members are reflected on the cover page of their group report;

·        each member MUST be responsible for one or multiple section(s) and attach his/her names to the section(s); as the individual contribution of respective students will worth 20% of the total 50% for the group assignment

 

Added to the above, each member must complete and submit a confidential individual self- and peer-assessment form for rewarding individuals’ contribution (i.e. 30% of the 50%)in the final group work submission.

Similarly, a conventional assessment process will be adopted, whereby students will be given a detailed assessment criteria together with the assignment brief. Upon completion of assessment, students will be given detailed comments as to how they could improve their work.
